channel.title: LinuxMint, any good general purpose editors?
channel.description:
I moved to LinuxMint yesterday and I'm not regretting it. The console is SOOOOOO much easier to use, the layout is smooth and it's not having the freeze-ups I used to have with Windows 7.
One thing I found that LinuxMint didn't have was a good editor. Pluma was built-in and I installed Gedit but they don't function properly. They highlight the syntax, ok but still stuff like indentation isn't working. I looked up if N++ worked for Linux but it's built only for Windows. Does anyone have any recomendations? I'm NOT looking for an IDE. I'm looking for a multi-purpose editor that supports at least syntax highlighting and indentation for the following languages: * Java * C/C++/Objective-C * Lua

item.title: LinuxMint, any good general purpose editors?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Hash1, post:17, topic:517629”][quote author=t4 link=topic=635890.msg4288364#msg4288364 date=1366766578]
No, use a real operating system. Use vim.
[/quote]

Vim for syntax-highlighting and programming? Eww.[/quote]
Either a troll or clearly no experience with vim

Read full topic

item.title: LinuxMint, any good general purpose editors?
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:12, topic:517629”][quote author=tigerclan link=topic=635890.msg4288069#msg4288069 date=1366728322]

[quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=635890.msg4288060#msg4288060 date=1366726434]

Definitely Sublime Text 2. I’m not sure why you would want to develop with Objective C on a Linux system though, I think it’s pretty useless on anything other then a Mac (could be wrong). And what version of Mint did you install? Because gedit is included with Nadia (Linux Mint 14, newest version).
[/quote]Gedit’s probably been on all of them for a while.

it didn’t come with my installation of lubuntu lol
[/quote]I meant it probably came with the recent versions of Mint. Lubuntu comes with leafpad instead afaik.[/quote]

yeah, leafpad sucks so bad lol

Read full topic

item.source: LinuxMint, any good general purpose editors?

item.title: LinuxMint, any good general purpose editors?
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

smart indent can be toggled in gedit’s settings.

st2 is a great cross-platform editor and it’s pretty similar to npp (although some individuals such as myself would consider it superior for several reasons that i can elaborate on if you wish). the trial is free (it’s proprietary though if that concerns you). check it out if you don’t mind downloading something not in the official software repo (i think there are ppas for it too). http://www.sublimetext.com/2

[size=1pt]if you’re feeling lucky and brave and smart and willing to try something with a huge learning curve you also might want to give vim a shot.[/size]

(by the way, compatibility usually thrives from distro to distro with little hassle. stop asking for linux mint specific programs because that’s just plain silly.)

Read full topic
item.source: LinuxMint, any good general purpose editors?
